text: folks, especially the non-UKers, what is your opinion on these bet brokers like bet-in-asia or stuff like that? looks tempting on one side because they give you access to horse races through white-label versions of betfair, but on the other hand, it looks sketchy as hell..

text: The Indian BF clones/partners/whatever they are have been known to welch on bets without much justification, for example alleging market manipulation on very thin grounds. I helped provide evidence for one syndicate which had been done out of several hundred thousand with no real reason (horse racing). That whole world is very murky and best approached with caution.

text: Based on past work for clients, my clients worked on the principle that it's quite possible to lose your money to a dodgy operator in an Asian country. Not likely, but possible. So if you are cashed up, and can deal with a loss of what you have with them, then feel free to take the risk. There would be no legal recourse through normal channels

text: I don't know the exact criteria for an AM but if you've won £500k you'll very likely be managed and there are some accounts well below that who generate a lot of com. I think there are about 300 premium accounts - which is what they call managed winning accounts. The other category used to be called a 'VIP' account and that's the kind you don't want - it's a managed mug. As far as I know there are 3 AMs (unless they've recently recruited more). Not all premium accounts are equal, the the biggest accounts are managed directly by the head of the team and the other two manage the rest of us. Whoever your manager is they will stand you a decent lunch.
